review.title: Extending DLR with Labelled Tuples, Projections, Functional Dependencies and Objectification (full version)
review.abstract: We introduce an extension of the n-ary description logic DLR to deal with attribute-labelled tuples (generalising the positional notation), with arbitrary projections of relations (inclusion dependencies), generic functional dependencies and with global and local objectification (reifying relations or their projections). We show how a simple syntactic condition on the appearance of projections and functional dependencies in a knowledge base makes the language decidable without increasing the computational complexity of the basic DLR language.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this paper, we present the DLR language, which extends the n-ary description logicsDLR [Calvanese et al., 1998; Baader et al., 2003] and DLRifd [Calvanese et al., 2001] as follows: - semantics is based on attribute-designated tuples: an element of a tupel is identified by an attribute and not by its position in the tupel, e.g. the relation person has attributes first name, last name, age, size with instance: x first name: Enrico, last name: Franconi, age: 53, size: 1.90y; - renaming attributes is possible, e.g. restoring position semantics: first name, last name, age, heightí 1,2,3,4; - it can express projections of relationships and thus express synergy dependencies of relationships, e.g. first name, last name, surname; - it can express multiple attributes, i.e. multiplications of a person and thus multiplications of a person.

sections.heading: 6 Acknowledgements
sections.text: We thank Alessandro Mosca for working with us on all the preparatory work necessary to understand how these technical results can be achieved.
